text: P1: Security argument overstated — /bin/ps is invoked via Process() with fixed args, not a shell
P1: Complexity estimate understated — analyzer code (analyze.py:136-143) breaks on format change, README needs update
P1: Schema migration for existing logs not addressed — 30-day mixed-format window
P1: 'No downside' claim is false — loss of non-app processes and CPU/MEM data
P1: Consider libproc/sysctl as alternative to NSRunningApplication
P2: Analyzer architecture is batch-oriented; --follow needs parallel execution path, not a small add-on
P2: Log rotation handling is non-trivial due to size-based rotation with local-time filenames
P2: kqueue dismissal on portability grounds is weak for macOS-only tool
P2: Consider --stream mode reading from stdin, let tail -F handle rotation
P3: Comment-based consistency enforcement is inadequate for dual build paths
P3: SPM migration rejected too quickly — install.sh could call swift build -c release
P4: Bootstrap paradox — analyze.py exits if logs missing, but status is needed precisely then
P4: LaunchAgent identity ambiguity (label vs plist filename) complicates status reliability
P4: Fixed 10-minute stale threshold false-alarms during sleep unless sleep state is considered
P5: Blanket deferral ignores middle ground — window-change signal without titles
P5: Complexity claims (200+ lines, manual CFRelease) unsubstantiated
Priority ordering presented as high confidence despite acknowledged low evidence
Periodic PROCESS_SNAPSHOT events are underutilized in analyzer — no dedicated section
Self-review points SC-06 and SC-07 are partly performative — admitted but not corrected in draft
P3 is priority #1 but has unresolved AppKit/SPM linking question
Testing/migration validation gates still under-specified for P1 and P3
Sleep-aware staleness suppression can hide real daemon failures (false negatives)
P2 benefits from Package.swift is a weak dependency claim — P2 is Python-side work
